title: 111_hr2091
content: The "Plastic Bag Reduction Act of 2009" imposes a tax on single-use carryout bags under a new subchapter in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Plastic Bag Reduction Act of 2009" imposes a tax on single-use carryout bags. The tax amount varies from $0.05 to $0.25 per bag depending on the date. Retailers are responsible for collecting the tax. Single-use carryout bags are defined as bags used by retail sellers at the point of sale with a customer. The term 'single-use carryout bags' refers to bags used by retail sellers at the point of sale with a customer, with exceptions for reusable bags and bags designed for specific purposes like packaging bulk items or prescription drugs. The tax on single-use carryout bags must be passed through to the customer and separately stated on the receipt. Retailers must keep records of the number of bags purchased and amounts passed through to the customer. The first retail sale and use of bags are treated as a sale. The first retail sale and use of bags are treated as a sale, with rules similar to section 4002 applying. A new section is added for a Carryout Bag Recycling Program in the tax code. "SEC. 6433. QUALIFIED SINGLE-USE CARRYOUT BAG RECYCLING PROGRAM." The Secretary will pay a retailer an amount for each single-use carryout bag provided to a customer if the retailer has a qualified carryout bag recycling program in effect. The applicable amount is $0.01 for transactions between January 1, 2010, and January 1, 2015, and $0.05 for transactions after January 1, 2015. The qualified single-use carryout bag recycling program requires retailers to pass through the tax imposed by section 4056, track the total number of bags purchased, display "PLEASE RETURN TO A PARTICIPATING STORE FOR RECYCLING" on each bag, and provide carryout bag collection bins at retail locations. Establishment of Trust Fund for single-use carryout bag recycling program, including requirements for retailers to maintain records, provide reusable bags, and establish collection bins at retail locations. Establishment of a Single-Use Carryout Bag Trust Fund. The Single-Use Carryout Bag Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by appropriations and credits. Money received in the Treasury is transferred to the Trust Fund. The Trust Fund can be used for grants to States and localities with bag taxes similar to section 4056, and for payments under section 6433. Additionally, there is a provision for transferring funds to the Land and Water Conservation Fund. The Secretary transfers amounts from the Trust Fund to the Land and Water Conservation Fund based on transactions subject to tax under section 4056. The amounts transferred are $0.01 per transaction from 2010 to 2015, and $0.05 per transaction from 2015 onwards. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness of reducing single-use carryout bags and promoting recycling. The study will address measures to enhance effectiveness, including the tax amount on each bag, and assess the potential impact of taxing other products like food wrappers. A report on the study will be submitted by December 31, 2012. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on reducing single-use carryout bags and promoting recycling, including assessing the impact of taxing other products like food wrappers. A report will be submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. Amendments will be made to the table of subchapters for chapter 31 of the Code. Amendments were made to the table of sections for subchapters in the Code to include a Qualified single-use carryout bag recycling program and a Single-Use Carryout Bag Trust Fund. These amendments will take effect on January 1, 2010.
